headline: PM Clashes with Opposition Over Kiwi Exodus as Controversial Workplace and Gambling Bills Advance
summary: Parliament was dominated by heated exchanges over the cost of living and the record number of New Zealanders leaving the country, as the government advanced contentious legislation aimed at overhauling employment laws and regulating online gambling for the first time. Debates on major reforms to resource management and water services also featured prominently, underscoring a day of significant policy clashes between the government and opposition parties.

topicSummaries.topic: Cost of Living and Kiwi Exodus Dominate Question Time
topicSummaries.content: The Prime Minister faced a sustained barrage of questions from the Opposition regarding the cost of living and the number of New Zealanders leaving for Australia. Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins challenged the government's economic record, pointing to rising costs and claiming 184,000 Kiwis had left since the government took office. The Prime Minister defended his government's actions, blaming the previous administration for high inflation and interest rates, and highlighted policies like the expansion of the FamilyBoost childcare subsidy and tax relief as key measures to support working families.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: Does he consider it a success that 184,000 Kiwis—equivalent to the entire population of Hamilton—have left New Zealand under his leadership?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: The reason people leave a country is because they think they can earn higher incomes somewhere else. What this Government's doing is making sure that we fix the economy. Because why are they leaving? They're leaving because there was high inflation, high interest rates, the economy shrunk, and people were put out of work. And that was because of the last Government.

topicSummaries.topic: Major Employment Law Overhaul Passes First Reading
topicSummaries.content: The government's Employment Relations Amendment Bill passed its first reading, proposing significant changes to workplace laws. The bill introduces a new test to determine whether a worker is a contractor or an employee, a move opponents claim will undermine the rights of gig economy workers like Uber drivers. It also establishes a $180,000 income threshold above which employees cannot pursue personal grievances for unjustified dismissal, and removes the '30-day rule' that gives new employees the terms of a collective agreement for their first month. Minister Brooke van Velden argued the changes would provide business certainty and flexibility, while Labour and the Greens described it as a direct attack on workers' rights.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Brooke van Velden (Minister for Workplace Relations and Safety)
keyExchanges.quote: The policies in this bill aim to restore business confidence to hire and to increase opportunities for Kiwis. Flexible labour markets are the best environment for businesses to grow.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Jan Tinetti (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This is yet another piece of legislation that is a direct attack on workers. At least this time we are seeing that we're going to have a select committee process—well, I hope that's what we're going to have—

topicSummaries.topic: Online Casino Gambling Bill Divides House in Conscience Vote
topicSummaries.content: A bill to regulate online casino gambling for the first time passed its first reading on a conscience vote. The Online Casino Gambling Bill, introduced by Minister Brooke van Velden, seeks to create a regulated market by licensing up to 15 online casino operators. The government argues this will bring an unregulated industry into the light, introducing harm minimisation measures and generating tax revenue. However, the proposal was met with strong opposition from Labour, the Greens, and Te Pāti Māori, who argued that licensing 15 operators was far too many and would lead to a saturation of advertising and an increase in gambling harm, particularly in vulnerable communities.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Brooke van Velden (Minister of Internal Affairs)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill is about ensuring that New Zealanders who wish to play on online casinos can do so, on regulated websites in a safer market where operators follow our requirements for harm minimisation and consumer protection and contribute financially to New Zealand.

keyExchanges.speaker: Tākuta Ferris (Te Pāti Māori)
keyExchanges.quote: Although it may be true that a regulated online gambling industry is better than an unregulated one, gambling does nothing for Māori. Never has, never will, and neither will this bill. We do not need overseas companies profiting off our misery.

topicSummaries.topic: Government's 'Local Water Done Well' Bill Passes Second Reading
topicSummaries.content: The third and final bill in the government's water services reform package, the Local Government (Water Services) Bill, passed its second reading. This legislation solidifies the 'Local Water Done Well' model, which replaces the previous Labour government's controversial 'Three Waters' entities. Minister Simon Watts stated the bill provides a flexible framework that maintains local ownership and decision-making while ensuring financial sustainability. Opposition parties heavily criticised the bill, arguing it lacks adequate funding mechanisms for councils, will lead to significant rates rises, and fails to address the country's long-term water infrastructure deficit.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Simon Watts (Minister of Local Government)
keyExchanges.quote: This is the third and final piece of legislation for implementing Local Water Done Well, the Government's plan to address water services challenges. It is a complete legislative framework for New Zealand's water services delivery system.

keyExchanges.speaker: Tangi Utikere (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Labour, it will come as no surprise, will not support inadequate legislation in this space. We will not support something that is significantly underdone and is, basically, subpar as a solution for communities all around New Zealand.

topicSummaries.topic: RMA Reform Bill Advances, Paving Way for Housing Density and Streamlined Consents
topicSummaries.content: The Resource Management (Consenting and Other System Changes) Amendment Bill passed its second reading, marking a key step in the government's phased reform of the RMA. The bill aims to speed up consenting for infrastructure, housing, and farming. A major component provides a bespoke solution for Auckland to progress housing intensification while allowing it to opt-out of the Medium Density Residential Standards (MDRS) to better manage flood-prone areas. Minister Chris Bishop also flagged that a future amendment would mandate high-density zoning around Auckland's new City Rail Link stations. Labour expressed support for some aspects but raised concerns over changes to freshwater farm plan rules and the weakening of environmental protections.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (Minister responsible for RMA Reform)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill makes some quick and targeted—well, not that quick, but it makes some targeted changes to the existing RMA in order to unlock productivity, housing growth, economic growth, and primary sector changes.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Rachel Brooking (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Labour has been supportive of the bill, but not all of the bill, and I'll go through that in some detail. But we do have some very real questions for the Government Ministers in that committee stage—so I want to foreshadow that now.

topicSummaries.topic: Health Minister Accused of 'Fake Doctor Visits' to Meet Targets
topicSummaries.content: Health Minister Simeon Brown faced accusations of misleading the public over health targets after Labour's Dr Ayesha Verrall claimed Nelson patients were being given "appointments that don't exist, with doctors that aren't there" in order to meet waitlist targets. The allegation centres on an IT system issue where patients waiting over four months for a specialist appointment were sent letters with bookings for the coming months. Minister Brown vehemently rejected the claim, calling it a "beat-up from the unions" and stating his focus was on ensuring the 23 affected patients, who had been on a waitlist for over two years, would be seen.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Ayesha Verrall (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Will he take responsibility for Nelson patients being given appointments that don't exist, with doctors that aren't there, in order to say he's meeting the target?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Simeon Brown (Minister of Health)
keyExchanges.quote: That question is just repeating the beat-up from the unions in Nelson, who are trying to politicise an IT system rather than celebrate the fact that all 23 of those patients now have bookings over the next three months and will be seen.

conclusion: The government advanced its reform agenda on multiple fronts, but was dogged by opposition attacks linking its economic policies to a growing exodus of New Zealanders.
